Communities have come together over the past nine months but there has been an horrific increase in instances of domestic abuse
column4: so much so that there is a specific Garda operation for this. The reason I am talking about Covid-19
column5: domestic violence and resources during a debate on a Private Members’ motion on greyhounds is that the greyhound industry receives considerable sums in Exchequer funding. The amount for 2021 is said to be €19.2 million
column6: which includes the increase of €2.4 million in funding that the motion seeks to reverse. I am talking about this because people have said to me that greyhounds are getting more money than women’s services. As well as reversing that funding increase of €2.4 million
column7: the motion calls on the Government to increase funding for the welfare of greyhounds and to phase out State support for the greyhound industry. Why is the State still funding this industry? Yesterday
column8: I spoke to the Regulation of Lobbying (Amendment) Bill 2020 and it is worth noting the strength of the greyhound industry lobby in this country. The "RTÉ Investigates: Greyhounds Running for Their Lives" programme aired in 2019 and documented some of the cruel acts taking place in the industry. Advocacy groups have told us that greyhounds are being overbred and that some 6
column9: 000 are culled every year. As people have become more aware of the industry
column10: attendance has dropped. It is not the fun social event it once was. The public could no longer ignore the stories of drugging
column11: maltreatment and export. It would be remiss of me not to mention former Deputies who undertook significant work on the welfare of greyhounds in the previous Dáil. Maureen O’Sullivan and Tommy Broughan often raised the important issues of animal welfare and the treatment and export of greyhounds. Tommy Broughan worked with Dogs Trust Ireland to bring forward the Welfare of Greyhounds (Amendment) Bill 2017. The former Deputies and the now MEP
column12: Clare Daly
column13: worked with Senators Higgins and Ruane on Committee Stage of the Government’s Greyhound Racing Bill 2018 to try to improve it. The Government did not listen to everything we called for then but I hope it will listen now
column14: although I doubt that very much. The public are more aware than ever of our public spending and the areas they want the Government to support
column15: but as usual it will be behind the people. The greyhound racing industry is so problematic. The serious issues and maltreatment of these dogs have been widely documented. Live hare coursing should also be banned. I know there are some greyhound breeders and owners who adore their dogs and treat them well but
column16: unfortunately
column17: there are many who see them as money-making machines
column18: and weaker pups and litters as collateral damage. What about the older
column19: retired greyhounds? When they are no longer of use
column20: what happens to them? Greyhound racing encourages gambling too
column21: which has its own detrimental effects on society. Why is this industry supported by taxpayers' money? Ideally
column22: I would like this type of racing to be done away with as a sport
column23: but if it must still happen
column24: it should certainly not be supplemented by the public purse
column25: nor should it take scarce resources away from areas such as domestic violence
column26: housing
column27: health provision and so on. I cannot let the moment pass without mentioning the Claire Byrne interview on Wednesday last
column28: 18 November
column29: where a Fine Gael councillor
column30: David McManus
column31: repeatedly lied about the 33
column32: 000 jobs in the industry. I commend Deputy Cairns on bringing forward the motion and returning the issue to the floor of the House. I am more than happy to support the motion and believe that it is important for us to defund the greyhound industry.

column1: #JackieCahill	unknown-#JackieCahill-party	unknown-#JackieCahill-dob	unknown-#JackieCahill-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	19	I respect the right of the Social Democrats to bring forward the motion; we live in a democracy. Nevertheless
column2: I strenuously oppose their views and will do so with every breath in my body. Yesterday
column3: the party posted a video to social media that had been recorded at the gates of Leinster House. It featured a lurcher. It clearly illustrated the lack of understanding the Social Democrats have about the exact role that this industry plays in rural Ireland. I am privileged to have owned greyhounds and I also have the leg of a horse from time to time. It is part of our heritage and culture. I am not going to talk about the economics of it but it is part of rural Ireland. If the Social Democrats get their way on greyhound racing
column4: what target will be next? Will it be point-to-point racing
column5: hunting
column6: shooting or fishing? These are all sports that we grew up with and that we will defend. They are part of our heritage. Yesterday
column7: the Minister appeared before the Joint Committee on Agriculture and the Marine
column8: which I am privileged to chair
column9: and the opportunity was there for Members of Dáil Éireann and the Seanad to cross-examine him about what the money is being spent on and where it is going. We had a detailed discussion on the fund and the committee referred the matter back to the Dáil and the Seanad
column10: where it will be voted on
column11: as is the democratic process. This is not about the money
column12: however. It is about a way of life and our heritage
column13: and we will not take any more. Rural Ireland and people who love their sports have taken enough. A strict line is being drawn on our pursuits. I will leave out the economics. The regulations are there and are being stringently enforced. There has been much talk of the "RTÉ Investigates" programme. Some of that footage was recorded outside this jurisdiction
column14: while other parts were very dated. There is no place for people who break the regulations. We have a strictly regulated industry and will defend it to the last.

column1: #JoeCarey	unknown-#JoeCarey-party	unknown-#JoeCarey-dob	unknown-#JoeCarey-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	20	I oppose the motion put forward by the Social Democrats. The proposed increase in the Horse and Greyhound Fund is necessary
column2: given the severe impact of Covid-19 on the horse and greyhound industries. The most recent economic assessment of the industry was undertaken by the economist Jim Power in November 2017. Mr. Power's report found that the greyhound industry delivers €302 million to the economy
column3: with 12
column4: 371 people deriving economic benefit from it. Many families have been raised thanks to the owning
column5: breeding and training of greyhounds
column6: getting children through college and school from the earnings delivered from the industry. Greyhound racing is an integral part of rural Irish life. It is simply outrageous to hear the constant
column7: unjustified bashing of the industry. These attacks are littered with false claims and allegations and are deliberately designed to undermine greyhound racing. Yesterday's publicity stunt by Deputy Cairns
column8: where she stood outside the gates of Leinster House with a lurcher and then went on to say it was an abandoned greyhound
column9: is further evidence of the false claims being put forward.Today's motion is another direct attack on rural Ireland by the Social Democrats
column10: an urban-based party that is determined to ban greyhound racing
column11: coursing
column12: horse racing
column13: point-to-point racing
column14: hunting and all other rural pursuits. The repeated insulting claims of widespread appalling mistreatment of greyhounds by people involved in the sport are simply not true. The chief inspector of the Irish Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals told the Oireachtas Joint Committee on Agriculture and the Marine that the number of contacts the organisation receives concerning greyhounds is negligible. At a time when many industries are closed because of Covid-19
column15: it is incredible that the Social Democrats Party is trying to close down this vital industry for rural Ireland.

column1: #CharlieMcConalogue	unknown-#CharlieMcConalogue-party	unknown-#CharlieMcConalogue-dob	unknown-#CharlieMcConalogue-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	21	I thank all the Deputies who contributed to the debate. There is a range of factors that justify continued Government support for the greyhound sector. The programme for Government contains a strong commitment to ensuring that there is a continued improvement in animal welfare within the industry. Future funding of the sector is contingent
column2: on an annual basis
column3: on welfare standards being upheld and compliance with those standards being strictly monitored. Like many other industries
column4: the greyhound sector is particularly affected by the Covid-19 crisis. The most recent economic assessment of the industry
column5: undertaken by Jim Power Economics in November 2017
column6: outlined how the sector delivers a significant impact for the national economy
column7: with 12
column8: 300 people deriving an economic benefit directly from it. According to its annual report for 2019
column9: Rásaíocht Con Éireann employs 125 full-time staff and 112 part-time staff
column10: measured in full-time equivalents
column11: with approximately 700 casual staff also employed at peak periods. The greyhound industry is predominantly rural but it does have a strong urban base. It has been significantly impacted by the Covid crisis as a result of the requirement for behind-door racing
column12: or the absence of racing
column13: for much of this year. Recovery of the industry will require ongoing Government support to aid the restoration of normal levels of activity and adequately manage welfare issues in the process. The future of the industry is dependent on a strong governance platform and the industry achieving the highest standards of integrity and welfare
column14: founded on a strong regulatory system. Provisions in the Greyhound Racing Act 2019
column15: which came into effect in May last year
column16: will make a real difference in this regard. The legislation strengthens the legal basis for the industry
column17: with a view to fortifying the integrity of the greyhound racing sector and improving provision for greyhound traceability. In accordance with the requirements of the Act
column18: Rásaíocht Con Éireann has conducted a procurement process for the introduction of a new traceability system. It expects to have the system operational by the end of this year
column19: with statutory regulation to follow on from that. This will provide a very strong mechanism to ensure that racing greyhounds are registered and traceable throughout their lives and that enforcement mechanisms are in place. It will provide for the recording of important events in the life of a racing greyhound
column20: including birth
column21: microchipping
column22: registration
column23: racing career
column24: changes of ownership
column25: trainer and location
column26: export
column27: retirement and end of life. The sections of the Act commenced last month signal a new era for the greyhound racing sector. They facilitate Rásaíocht Con Éireann in focusing on its key priority objective of achieving the highest standards of care and welfare of greyhounds. There is a very strong commitment to improved animal welfare in the programme for Government
column28: as I indicated
column29: and future funding is contingent on meeting the required standards. It is crucial
column30: as we go forward
column31: that we continue to support the sector for all of the reasons I have outlined. We recognise that it is an important part of our heritage and tradition in many rural and urban areas. It is important that the State should recognise that tradition and
column33: acknowledge the significant contribution the industry makes to economic life in those areas. We have had a very active debate
column34: with clear positions set out by various speakers. The Government is very clear in its support for the sector. The Social Democrats also have a clear view on the matter. At yesterday's meeting of the agriculture committee
column35: Deputy Cairns was the only member to speak against continued funding for the sector
column36: but there are others who share her views. Some people are trying to hold to both sides of the track on the issue. I note that Sinn Féin is not supporting the increased funding of €2.6 million in the budget
column37: which recognises the pressure the sector is under as a result of the Covid crisis
column38: but it does support the existing funding. If my recollection serves me right
column39: the party opposed that funding when it was announced last year. The view Sinn Féin Deputies give and the position they take on this issue depends on who they are talking to about it. We must all be clear on where we stand on the issue. From the Government's point of view
column40: and in accordance with the programme for Government
column41: the industry deserves support. We recognise the very strong efforts by Rásaíocht Con Éireann to ensure that there is oversight and transparency in regard to the welfare of greyhounds in the industry. We also recognise the commitment and care shown by those involved in the sector towards their animals. In any instances where that is not the case
column42: we are committed to ensuring there are mechanisms in place to intervene and address it. Situations where animals are not properly cared for cannot be tolerated.

column1: #CianOCallaghan	unknown-#CianOCallaghan-party	unknown-#CianOCallaghan-dob	unknown-#CianOCallaghan-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	22	I am sharing time with Deputy Cairns. I commend her on bringing forward this motion and I thank all the Deputies from the different groupings for their contributions to the debate. It is regrettable that Government time was not set aside for this important debate and that it must instead be taken in the limited time available for Private Members' business. Government members often say that Opposition parties do not offer solutions or only put forward solutions that cost money. This motion is constructive. It aims to save money
column2: improve animal welfare and redirect much needed resources into other areas. The motion is about animal cruelty but it is also about what we prioritise
column3: as a Dáil and as a society. It is not a radical motion. All we are proposing is that the market should decide what happens to the greyhound racing industry and that it should no longer be propped up with State subsidies. There should be a very strong case and rationale for propping up any industry in that way
column4: but I have not heard any such strong case or rationale in this debate. The one argument that has been made which does have a measure of validity relates to the importance of the jobs in the industry. However
column5: if resources being put into it were redirected to another area
column6: we would retain and create jobs in that way. Retaining jobs is not sufficient rationale for State subsidies to the sector. I do not agree with the argument put forward by the Labour Party that we must subsidise the industry in order to be able to scrutinise it. If that argument applies in this case
column7: does it apply everywhere else? Does every industry have a claim to State subsidies on the basis that we can only regulate and scrutinise those sectors that are subsidised by the taxpayer? That does not make any sense. We must be cognisant of the impact of this particular industry on gambling addiction
column8: taking account of the clear power of the gambling lobbying industry in terms of its influence on politics. Several speakers referred to greyhound racing being part of our culture
column9: tradition and heritage. We cannot make decisions about how we prioritise resources based simply on what happened in the past. If we consider some of the areas that are not getting the resources they should
column10: the culture and heritage argument does not make sense. In the context of the €19.2 million that is put into this industry
column11: a relevant comparison is the funding provided this year for people who have become homeless and the resources it would take to ensure they get a long-term
column12: secure Housing First tenancy. The people involved have complex needs. They include people who are sleeping rough
column13: people who are in and out of emergency shelters
column14: and people with addiction
column15: mental health and other complex issues. The amount we are spending
column16: as a State and a society
column17: on providing long-term
column18: secure Housing First tenancies for that group of people is €2.9 million this year.If we redirected some of the resources for the greyhound industry into long-term
column19: secure Housing First tenancies
column20: we could ensure that everyone who has a need in this regard could have that need met. It is not part of our culture
column21: heritage or tradition to have people who are homeless left in those situations. It does not speak to us
column22: as a society
column23: at all
column24: and yet this is an area in respect of which we are not providing sufficient funding. For the sake of the kind of sums of money that we are talking about
column25: we could be making real inroads. That is the choice that is being made today by the Government in deciding to put additional resources into the greyhound industry
column26: which
column27: in my view
column28: does not have a future and the time of which has come. In any event
column29: let us remove the State subsidies. If there is a demand for the industry
column30: and I do not believe there is
column31: let it be self-sufficient

column1: #HollyCairns	unknown-#HollyCairns-party	unknown-#HollyCairns-dob	unknown-#HollyCairns-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	23	I will start by addressing some of the blatant misinformation aired by Deputies this morning. Sinn Féin and the Government stated that €302 million is generated for the economy by the greyhound industry. There were 1
column2: 606 race meetings last year and the average attendance was 288. Are we to believe that every meeting generates €188
column3: 000? The other claim is that some of the money comes in from tourism but we all know that the vast majority of tourists do not come to Ireland to go to greyhound racing tracks. Another common feature of the debate has been the disputing of the figures. After the RTÉ documentary
column4: Greyhound Racing Ireland filed a complaint to the Broadcasting Authority of Ireland about it. The authority investigated the complaint in full
column5: rejected it in its entirety and found instead that "the programme was a comprehensive exploration of the topic in a factual manner which was fair
column6: objective and impartial." It is important to put that on the record again. I am also constantly hearing that we are referring to all trainers as terrible people who are involved in animal cruelty. I do not know how many times we have to say that we are aware not all trainers treat their dogs badly. Indeed
column7: many of those trainers have been in touch to thank us for tabling this motion because they are so aware of how badly dogs are treated in the industry. Many Deputies talked about employment and support for rural areas and help for farmers
column8: which is laughable. The vast majority of rural people
column9: farmers and fishing communities could think of so many preferable things to spend one quarter of a billion euro on. Rural populations are concerned about Brexit
column10: about the immoral prices farmers are receiving for their product and a lack of State services. These are the issues on which the Government needs to be spending our public money. Predictably
column11: some Deputies labelled this motion as blatantly anti-rural. This is a simplistic argument that paints all rural Ireland as uniform and conservative by default. This is not only insulting; it is simply untrue. Just because we are from rural areas does not mean we are unable to understand facts or engage in meaningful debate. A Red C poll conducted in 2019 found that only 16% of people support this industry. It is simply not true to say that the Government is representing all of rural Ireland. Claiming to have a monopoly on speaking for rural Ireland is
column12: quite simply
column13: ridiculous. The Government's amendment
column14: and
column15: indeed
column16: the Labour Party
column17: speak of the great progress that will be made in animal welfare
column18: in traceability and in greater accountability. The Government is so confident about this it is willing to give the industry €2.4 million but we know that this is blatant lip-service. Attempts by Opposition Senators and Deputies in 2019 to have clear regulations in respect of export and breeding practices were disregarded so that we know that the two most controversial malpractices in the industry will not be properly addressed. Independent organisations
column19: whistleblowers and other political parties know that this industry has proven to be incapable of the necessary reforms. Members of the public know this. They are voting with their feet. Sponsors and companies know this. It seems that the only people who do not know it are politicians and people who are invested in the industry. State funding has facilitated these significant deficiencies and overbreeding practices. It has insulated the industry from commercial reality and allowed Greyhound Racing Ireland to ignore public opinion. This has to stop. We have an opportunity to do it now. The Government's decision to give an extra €2.4 million to the industry in the budget
column20: ratified by the Joint Committee on Agriculture and the Marine yesterday
column21: can and should be halted. The remaining investment should be put towards the gradual winding down of a declining industry. Imagine for a second if the greyhound racing industry did not exist and my colleagues and I in the Social Democrats came in here today and proposed it
column22: using the same arguments that have been used to defend the funding of the industry. It is difficult to imagine but
column23: I suppose
column24: the motion on the matter would go something like this:I propose that we create an organised competitive sport of sorts
column25: in which dogs are raced around a track and people can go along and bet on them and I think that the Government should fund it to the tune of €19.2 million annually. The estimated loss for the taxpayer over the next four years will be approximately €30 million and
column26: in an attempt to avoid criticism for so many millions of euro of public money being pumped into a loss-making industry
column27: I suggest that a levy from the gambling industry be ring-fenced. Then we can use that to argue we are not using public money despite the fact that we are.Unfortunately
column28: in order to get dogs that I believe will run quick enough
column29: we will have to breed approximately 16
column30: 000 of them a year. This level of overbreeding will mean that we will have to kill about 6
column31: 000 of those dogs but we can defend this overbreeding and extreme cruelty by saying that some trainers treat their dogs well and that it is the lifeblood of rural Ireland.We also suggest that we tie it in as closely as possible with horse racing and claim that the two are intrinsically linked and that if you are against a loss-making racing industry that carries out the cruelty of greyhound racing
column32: you are also anti-horse racing. We could even go as far as to use the employment figures from horse racing to make the whole argument more robust.Finally
column33: if any of this is researched and aired or published
column36: we can just ignore it.We all know that this would be seen as the most outrageous thing imaginable but
column38: voting down the Social Democrats motion this evening is just as outrageous. I am calling on all parties to stop falling prey to lobbying. The solution is clear. We need to stand up and acknowledge the reality of this industry and stop turning a blind eye to its abuse and throwing more money at its failings.

column1: #SeanOFearghaillFF	unknown-#SeanOFearghaillFF-party	unknown-#SeanOFearghaillFF-dob	unknown-#SeanOFearghaillFF-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	24	In accordance with Standing Order 80(2)
column2: the division is postponed until the weekly division time this evening.

column1: #MaryLouMcDonald	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-party	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-dob	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	25	We are hearing very distressing news of the death of a man who lived in a tent close to Leinster House this morning. I express my condolences to his family and friends. I just wanted to acknowledge the passing of this man
column2: as it is almost six years to the day of Jonathan Corrie's death. The scandal of street homelessness and rough sleeping must be dealt with and it needs to happen soon. Today is International Day for the Elimination of Violence against Women and it marks the start of the 16-day campaign against domestic and gender-based violence. It is an annual campaign
column3: as the Taoiseach knows. I and others a stand up in this Chamber year after year and we recite the statistics that attempt to capture the horrific abuse and violence to which so many women and children are subjected. I have no doubt that everyone in the Dáil gets angry when they hear the heartbreaking stories of women who have been battered and emotionally broken by the violence inflicted upon them. The physical scars and bruises are all too apparent signposts of the trauma experienced
column4: often on a daily basis. The mental suffering
column5: the theft of victims' dignity
column6: confidence and sense of safety is less obvious but it frequently runs deeper. The fear cast by domestic violence
column7: by every beating
column8: every insult and every attempt to control and degrade is something that victims can overcome
column9: but the shadow of abuse is something they carry with them for the rest of their lives. It is time to face up to the fact that we have a real problem with domestic and gender-based violence in Ireland. It is time for the political system and Government to move past whatever unease they have about owning up to this fact. Violence against women and abuse behind closed doors and drawn curtains is at epidemic levels. The truth is that successive Governments have failed women and children who have been caught up in the horror of this abuse and until a Government confronts this problem with the honesty and the determination that it demands
column10: too many of the cries for help from abused women will go unanswered and unheard. The domestic violence support services providers in Ireland do remarkable work
column11: despite the fact that they have been underfunded for decades but while the abused women battled to survive the impact of the violence against them
column12: these service providers have been battling for resources
column13: funding and proper support from Government. I struggle to find words to express my anger about how this issue has been swept under the carpet for years. It is time our problem with domestic and gender-based violence was brought out into the open so that we can finally deliver policies
column14: supports and the funding necessary to tackle it head on. I welcome that emergency funding is provided to help services meet Covid-19-related costs; I am very glad the Taoiseach responded to that call. This will help with the immediate Covid challenge. However
column15: we must discuss and deal with the chronic lack of refuge places for women who need to escape the violence
column16: the abuse and the coercive control. Between March and June of this year
column18: 351 requests for refuge went unmet because the services were full. Nine counties have no refuge provision at all and this is a scandal. We know that incidents of domestic violence and abuse increase over the Christmas period. Victims
column19: their children and the services they rely on will face a very bleak picture in 2021 if the Government does not act. I
column20: therefore
column21: ask the Taoiseach on this day if he will now commit to ensuring the refuge shortages across the state are urgently addressed.

column1: #MichaelMartin	unknown-#MichaelMartin-party	unknown-#MichaelMartin-dob	unknown-#MichaelMartin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	26	I thank the Deputy for raising this issue on the International Day for the Elimination of Violence against Women. I share in the Deputy's expression of sympathies to the family and friends of the homeless individual who passed away. I also convey to the House my deep sadness at the passing of Trish Carrick
column2: whom we lately honoured and spoke of. I offer her husband Damien and children Ciarán
column3: Ríoghna
column4: Sorcha and Eoin our sincere sympathies. The programme for Government is very clear and has a very strong commitment to developing the third national strategy on domestic
column5: sexual and gender-based violence. There can be no toleration for violence against women in our society. We must do everything we possibly can to assist and support women and families who are the victims of unacceptable violence
column6: aggression and control. We have provided additional resources in the most recent budget to An Garda Síochána
column7: Tusla and other services that support women who have been victims of violence
column8: and we will continue to do that. The Minister for Justice is currently undertaking an audit of all services in this area
column9: which is an area all three Government parties want to prioritise. I assure the Deputy that if she wishes to engage with the Government on the areas or the specific locations where additional funding is required
column10: I will ensure that a response will occur in that regard. Particular funding has been given to Tusla in the budget to deal with the Covid-19 impact. We were particularly concerned about the elevation to level 5 following the experience of the first phase of the lockdown and its impact in the form of increased domestic violence. There was approximately €2 million in addition to approximately €25.3 million that had been allocated to these services for the entirety of 2020. The Deputy identified an important point about culture and the importance of ensuring within society at large that Ireland makes it very clear that
column11: as a society
column12: there can be absolutely no toleration whatsoever for gender-based violence. We must be absolute about that and then
column13: through education and through a variety of fora
column14: make sure that is clear. We must then ensure that the adequate supports are available so that people can be freed and be enabled to leave that coercive control and situations of violence
column15: safe in the knowledge that there is a pathway out of that experience that
column16: unfortunately
column17: too many in our society have had over the years. Across various Departments
column18: we want to do everything we possibly can to help victims or anybody who is at risk of domestic or sexual abuse. We will continue to be available to help in that regard and provide the necessary supports
column19: and also to strategically deal with this in an effective and comprehensive way.

column1: #MaryLouMcDonald	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-party	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-dob	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	27	I too wish to send our sympathies and regards to Damien Carrick on the loss of Trish
column2: a wonderful and courageous woman. The Taoiseach says there must be no toleration of violence against women and children in our society but the facts are that there is such a tolerance. The Taoiseach says we must do everything we can but everything is not being done. The Taoiseach says we must provide all of the necessary resources and on that point we agree. That
column3: however
column4: is not helped by playing games with big figures such as pointing to the additional money that has been given to Tusla when he knows not one cent of that money has been ring-fenced for domestic violence services. I know there is an audit under way. That could be a really important and significant intervention in all of this but only-----

column1: #SeanOFearghaillFF	unknown-#SeanOFearghaillFF-party	unknown-#SeanOFearghaillFF-dob	unknown-#SeanOFearghaillFF-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	28	Thank you
column2: Deputy.

column1: #MaryLouMcDonald	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-party	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-dob	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	29	-----if it means there is
column2: finally
column3: full transparency and honesty on this issue. The tolerance to this violence is a reality in Irish society and until we look that in the eye
column4: until we resolve to do something about it on a consistent basis and until it is front and centre in government policy we will continue year on year with people like me and the Taoiseach-----

column1: #SeanOFearghaillFF	unknown-#SeanOFearghaillFF-party	unknown-#SeanOFearghaillFF-dob	unknown-#SeanOFearghaillFF-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	30	The time is up Deputy. The Taoiseach to conclude on this important matter.

#MaryLouMcDonald	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-party	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-dob	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	31	-----standing up and bewailing this awful situation.

#MichaelMartin	unknown-#MichaelMartin-party	unknown-#MichaelMartin-dob	unknown-#MichaelMartin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	32	I thank the Deputy for raising this important issue. The programme for Government is very strong on this. It includes a number of relevant and key commitments
column2: including the development of the third national strategy
column3: which would place a priority on prevention and reduction and include a national preventative strategy. As I said
column4: an immediate audit is to be conducted in terms of responsibility for this area across different Government agencies and Departments. The Government is committed to implementing a plan for a future refuge space and to investigate the provision of paid leave and social protection provision to victims of domestic violence and to learn from the experience of the coercive control model in the United Kingdom
column5: including training for An Garda Síochána
column6: legal professionals and Courts Service personnel to ensure there is clear understanding of the offence. The Government wants to legislate to introduce domestic homicide reviews
column7: update the Sex Offenders Act 2001 to ensure convicted sex offenders are effectively managed and monitored
column8: enact a harassment and harmful communications Bill
column9: which the Minister has been speaking about
column10: to outlaw image-based sexual abuse and to prevent abusive sharing of intimate images online and
column11: crucially
column12: to implement the findings of the O'Malley review of supports for vulnerable witnesses in sexual violence cases to support victims.

column1: #MickBarry	unknown-#MickBarry-party	unknown-#MickBarry-dob	unknown-#MickBarry-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	33	There are reports that girls in Presentation College Carlow have been told not to wear leggings to school because they are too revealing of their bodies and make teachers uncomfortable. I understand the principal was on the radio this morning to challenge the reports. Clearly
column2: young people
column3: male and female
column4: in the school are very upset and believe that something very wrong happened here. There must be no place for victim blaming or body shaming in our schools and I ask that the Department investigates this matter further. Women and girls in our society have to put up with crap all their lives. Last week
column5: we saw sexual abuse on a grand scale with the mass sharing of intimate images online without consent. This morning
column6: researchers in Trinity and Maynooth tell us one in five Irish women have experienced rape. Today is the UN's international day for the elimination of violence against women. Globally
column7: each year as many women of reproductive age die from male violence as die from cancer. More suffer ill health as a result of this violence than suffer ill health from all of the traffic accidents and malaria cases in the world combined. The programme for Government describes sexual violence as an epidemic in our society. It has worsened in the Covid era and is now widely described as the shadow pandemic. I put it to the Taoiseach that he is not tackling it in the way he would tackle either an epidemic or a pandemic. With the pandemic the Government put society on a war footing. It organised lockdowns. The message to mask up
column8: socially distance and wash our hands comes at us every day
column9: and rightly so
column10: from radio
column11: television and the press. With the epidemic of sexual violence where are the emergency measures? The Taoiseach will commission a report here and a speech is made there and a few million euro is thrown at the problem from time to time. Gender-based violence and sexism are systemic issues. To a greater or lesser degree
column12: all of the institutions of the State and others are laced through with sexism. Mass feminist movements from Chile to Spain and from Poland to Peru are putting the system in the dock and pointing the finger at the establishment and the state. These movements offer real hope for the future. Two years ago
column13: eight months after the Belfast rape trial and at the time of the Cork rape trial
column14: my colleague
column15: Ruth Coppinger
column16: held up a thong in the Dáil in protest at a woman's clothing being used as evidence in a rape case. Two years on
column17: I will conclude by asking the following questions. Will the Taoiseach support the establishment of a task force on gender-based violence
column18: staff it with survivors
column19: advocates and women who work in the sector
column20: set aside a very healthy budget and pledge to implement its proposals? When will the Taoiseach act to stop victim blaming in the courts? When will he act to stop rape myths being used in trials? When will consent be made the central issue in rape cases?

column1: #MichaelMartin	unknown-#MichaelMartin-party	unknown-#MichaelMartin-dob	unknown-#MichaelMartin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	34	I thank the Deputy for raising this issue. In relation to the Presentation Secondary School in Carlow
column2: I did not hear the interview this morning but I agree with the Deputy that there is no place for victim shaming in any context and the Department of Education and the Minister will clearly receive a report on it. If the principal is challenging the report of what we read in the media
column3: in fairness to the House we have to seek out the full facts before passing commentary on it. In terms of the broader issue
column4: the Deputy summed it up when he said gender based violence and sexism are systemic. This is why it requires a systemic response. It cannot just be a response for six weeks or six months. Our response has to be truly systemic throughout our society. It has to be based on fundamental human values of respect for one another
column5: for the dignity of the human person and for the most basic of human values. Those basic human values
column6: particularly not to injure others and not in any shape or form ever raise a hand or engage in violence towards a woman
column7: are something that were ingrained in earlier years. It is wrong and it is horrific that the level of violence is as it is. We know from various reports on abuse itself that it has been systemic and it needs a systemic response. It needs constant engagement at all levels of society from the earliest ages in terms of inculcating basic values of respect
column8: toleration and understanding the dignity of the human being and that certain actions are never right in any circumstance. In my earlier response to Deputy McDonald
column9: I outlined the Government's broad range of commitments. The implementation of the O'Malley report is very important. The Minister
column10: Deputy McEntee
column11: is very committed to this area and is acting on a number of fronts
column12: not least the legislation to be brought in on the sharing of intimate images.

column1: #AlanKelly	unknown-#AlanKelly-party	unknown-#AlanKelly-dob	unknown-#AlanKelly-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	35	The Labour Party did that.

#MichaelMartin	unknown-#MichaelMartin-party	unknown-#MichaelMartin-dob	unknown-#MichaelMartin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	36	Let us not have a row about something that is important and good. We should press ahead and do it. Also in terms of the O'Malley report
column2: the Minister has already brought it to Cabinet and published it and is determined to take action and deal with this. In accordance with the commitments in the programme for the Government we are determined to do it.

column1: #MickBarry	unknown-#MickBarry-party	unknown-#MickBarry-dob	unknown-#MickBarry-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	37	In terms of the scale and horror of this issue
column2: Mary Crilly from the sexual violence centre in Cork recently said:I have yet to meet a homeless woman who hasn't been raped. They tend to say "I've lost count of the number of times that I've been raped."I welcome the fact there is to be a pilot scheme in Cork to provide a refuge for homeless rape victims but I ask the Taoiseach what is the timescale for this initiative to come to fruition. In all of Cork city and county there is one refuge for families who are victims of gender-based violence. There is space for six families there but it had to be restricted to two families during Covid. This is a sign of the scale of the failure of the Government and the State and the lack of investment in this issue. I listened to the Taoiseach when he said the Department of Education will clearly receive a report on the events in the school in Carlow. I ask him to comment that the Department will not just receive a report from the school authorities but will seek the views
column3: opinions and experiences of the students themselves on this issue.

column1: #MichaelMartin	unknown-#MichaelMartin-party	unknown-#MichaelMartin-dob	unknown-#MichaelMartin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	38	I recently met Mary Crilly from the Cork Rape Crisis Centre and I have had long engagement with her through her extraordinary work over the years on behalf of rape victims. When I was Minister for Health and Children
column2: we were involved in setting up the first forensic sexual violence centre in the South Infirmary Victoria University Hospital in Cork.Mary Crilly is a tireless worker. I met Mary Crilly
column3: Caitriona Twomey and Lavinia Kerwick at Cork Penny Dinners recently to discuss the phenomenon of the rape of homeless women and men. It was quite a shocking story that they had to tell. They have come forward with an idea around developing a pilot project to help the homeless and to protect the homeless from sexual violence and rape. I said I felt that was a very good idea and that I would pursue it with them and with the homeless authorities
column4: and that the local authority and the HSE would have to be involved. I said we would take a co-ordinated approach to dealing with this issue and then see if a model could be developed that could then be rolled out across the country. Given the evidence they brought forward to us
column5: it is an issue that merits that consideration
column6: although it will take a bit of time to get that up and running and to get it right.

column1: #CathalBerry	unknown-#CathalBerry-party	unknown-#CathalBerry-dob	unknown-#CathalBerry-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	39	I would like to focus my questions on Ireland’s air-sea rescue capability. It was a service that was provided exclusively by the Irish Air Corps for decades up to the year 2002
column2: when it was handed over and outsourced to a private company. Most members of the public will be familiar with the large red and white helicopters that sometimes fly overhead. What they may not be aware of is that these helicopters are not owned by the Irish Coast Guard
column3: nor are they even owned by the State. They are owned and operated by a foreign private helicopter company which is on a very lucrative contract from the Irish taxpayer. When I say “lucrative”
column4: I am talking about €600 million over a ten-year period
column5: or €5 million a month
column6: if one wants to look at it from that perspective. Not only is the contract very expensive
column7: it is also finite in time. At the end of the ten-year period
column8: Ireland is left with absolutely nothing. The helicopters will be taken away and we will have to go back to scratch to retender the contract again for another ten years. The reason I am bringing this up today and the reason it is so pertinent is that the process to renegotiate a new ten-year contract from 2023 onwards is shortly to get under way. It is estimated that approximately €1 billion will be used to provide this contract over the next ten years
column9: which is the financial equivalent of half of a national children's hospital
column10: so that is the scale of the project currently taking place. I raised this matter on budget day in October. I have been very heartened and encouraged by all of the Deputies who have supported what I have said. These are Deputies from all across the political divide
column11: on both sides of the Chamber. It is clear there is now an appetite to re-examine a better
column12: optimum model of delivery which would provide better value for money for the Irish taxpayer but also
column13: crucially
column14: provide a more sustainable and more sovereign service for the country. That is something the country deserves. For example
column15: we do not outsource policing in Dublin city to a private security firm; we resource An Garda Síochána to provide that policing capability on our behalf. Rather than funding a foreign private helicopter company to run a service for a fixed and finite period of time
column16: would it not make more sense to invest that money in the Irish Air Corps to provide a more sustained and sovereign service into the future? At the end of the ten years
column17: Ireland would still own the helicopters and we would not have to retender the contract after ten years.

column1: #MichaelMartin	unknown-#MichaelMartin-party	unknown-#MichaelMartin-dob	unknown-#MichaelMartin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	40	I thank the Deputy for raising this issue. There is currently a project under the remit of the Department of Transport to consider development of a new marine search and rescue
column2: SAR
column3: aviation contract for future service provision
column4: as the Deputy has outlined. The Deputy has been fair in saying the provision of search and rescue aviation services in Ireland has
column5: to a great extent
column6: involved a mix of private provision since the 1980s
column7: and has been fully provided on a 24-7 basis by a private entity since 2004
column8: with the Air Corps providing support
column9: including top cover support
column10: to the Coast Guard on an “as available” basis. As part of this ongoing project
column11: a preliminary appraisal of service provider options ruled out the option of either the Air Corps or the Coast Guard taking full responsibility for SAR aviation services in Ireland at that stage. However
column12: given its historical role in the area
column13: the Government would like to explore further the option of the Air Corps providing some element of the aviation services. I know the Minister for Defence
column14: Deputy Coveney
column15: has asked his officials to engage with the Department of Transport to explore this matter further and that is part of the detailed appraisal of SAR service provider options. It is important we get this right for everyone. As the Deputy said
column16: there is considerable State funding at play here and the provision of a life-saving service is the ultimate aim of all concerned. The next step in the process will be to bring a detailed business case to Government early next year
column17: with an appraisal of the viable options and a recommendation on the way forward to delivering this service and the procurement strategy to achieve it. The Department of Defence and the Department of Transport are liaising closely on this. Both the Naval Service and the Air Corps currently provide support to the Coast Guard on an “as available” basis and that will continue. It is a valuable role. I will engage with the Minister for Transport
column18: Deputy Ryan
column19: and the Minister for Defence
column20: Deputy Coveney
column21: on this issue. There is still time to develop the best option. I am conscious there has been a need for increased and ongoing investment in the Air Corps and also the retention of personnel. However
column22: there has been significant investment in equipment and personnel. The replacement of the Air Corps Cessna fleet
column23: as provided for in the White Paper
column24: with three larger aircraft
column25: which are equipped for intelligence
column26: surveillance
column27: target acquisition and reconnaissance
column28: has been completed. These aircraft
column29: which cost just over €43 million
column30: are now operational. In March
column31: a fourth PC-12 NG aircraft was purchased to provide very immediate additional fixed-wing capacity to meet the unique situation arising from the Covid-19 pandemic. The White Paper also provides for the replacement of the CASA 235s with larger
column33: which would enhance maritime surveillance and provide a greater degree of utility for transport and cargo carrying tasks. A contract for the supply of two C295 maritime patrol aircraft was entered into with Airbus Defence and Space in December 2019. The cost of the contract
column34: including equipment fit-out and ancillary support
column35: was approximately €221 million and the aircraft are scheduled for delivery in 2023. In terms of personnel
column36: a service commitments scheme for pilots was sanctioned by the Department of Public Expenditure and Reform and implemented in the third quarter of 2019
column37: which has had a stabilising effect on numbers. Other measures
column38: such as a recommissioning scheme for former Air Corps pilots
column40: and a range of initiatives which will see accelerated training through outsourcing is restoring capacity to the Air Corps as quickly as possible.

column1: #CathalBerry	unknown-#CathalBerry-party	unknown-#CathalBerry-dob	unknown-#CathalBerry-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	41	I thank the Taoiseach for that very useful response. I fully appreciate
column2: like everybody in the Chamber
column3: that there is huge demand on the Taoiseach’s time currently. I also understand that he gets the occasional direct flight from Baldonnel airbase directly to Brussels
column4: which is completely appropriate given his status as Taoiseach. Would he consider arriving an hour before his flight sometime early in the new year so he could visit the helicopter wing in Casement Aerodrome
column5: Baldonnel
column6: which is only a couple of hundred metres away? He could discuss this matter with the crews on the ground and see for himself the facilities
column7: aircraft and equipment that are available
column8: and get a sense of the tools and talent that are already available within the public service before we choose to outsource it to a private operator.

column1: #MichaelMartin	unknown-#MichaelMartin-party	unknown-#MichaelMartin-dob	unknown-#MichaelMartin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	42	In these Covid times
column2: it has been very occasional. That is a very good idea. I will certainly avail of that opportunity to visit and see at first hand the helicopters
column3: the equipment and the various facilities that are available in Baldonnel
column4: and I will ask for that to be facilitated. I will take the Deputy up on that suggestion
column5: which is a good idea.

column1: #MichaelMcNamara	unknown-#MichaelMcNamara-party	unknown-#MichaelMcNamara-dob	unknown-#MichaelMcNamara-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	43	For eight months now the State has been dealing with the threat posed by Covid-19. We are rightly told to follow the science
column2: but science is empirical and it is based on data. I am concerned by the lack of published data. Peer review and transparency are central to any scientific response. I want to focus in particular on the data on mental health. The National Self-Harm Registry Ireland in Cork ceased functioning for the duration of the first lockdown.At the end of August
column3: it started to collect data again
column4: both prospectively and retrospectively
column5: but at the time of the second lockdown there were no data available in respect of the first. However
column6: we were told that the national clinical programme for the assessment and management of persons presenting to emergency departments following self-harm - that is quite a mouthful - which is run by the College of Psychiatrists of Ireland and the HSE
column7: was collecting data throughout the duration of the first lockdown. Where are those data? Has they been collated? At the time we were announcing the second lockdown and this Dáil was voting to facilitate it
column8: I was standing where I am now when the Minister of State
column9: Deputy Mary Butler
column10: told me I would be provided with those data. I have not yet been provided with them and I have not managed to obtain them. The collection of those data is publicly funded. It is in the public interest that these HSE and College of Psychiatrists of Ireland programme data be collected. The programme is funded by the public so surely those data should be in the public domain to inform this House and the Government on the measures they take. Yesterday
column11: the Tánaiste talked about a third lockdown. We cannot go into a third lockdown without at least knowing the impact of the first one on mental health. I do not know whether those data are available. I am told they are but they may not be collated. If they are not collated
column12: they are of no benefit because we cannot consider the impact of data that have not been collated. Will the Taoiseach commit to publishing those data? There is a broader issue regarding publishing the data and evidence available to NPHET to ensure that they are transparent and can be peer reviewed. That is not to undermine NPHET. Peer review
column13: whether regarding the development of a vaccine or any medical or scientific response
column14: is central and we cannot do that without the transparent publication of data
column15: modelling codes and evidence.

column1: #MichaelMartin	unknown-#MichaelMartin-party	unknown-#MichaelMartin-dob	unknown-#MichaelMartin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	44	Data are extremely important in terms of the entire experience of Covid-19 and learning from the first lockdown
column2: which we did
column3: and then informing the experiences of different phases of Covid. For example
column4: coming out of the first phase when the country reopened and cases began to rise again during the August and September period
column5: we brought in a team from the HSE
column6: commissioning EY
column7: to look at all of that detail with greater analytical tools and to identify where outbreaks happened and what was the correlation
column8: what were the events and what were the combined circumstances that gave rise to spikes across the country. The Health Protection Surveillance Centre
column9: HPSC
column10: the HSE
column11: the Department of Health
column12: the Central Statistics Office and other Departments - the Deputy referenced the Department of Health - including the Departments of Enterprise
column13: Trade and Employment
column14: Finance
column15: Public Expenditure and Reform
column16: Social Protection and Justice
column17: have all been inputting into the assessment and the impacts Covid has had on the different sectors of society. That will inform how we exit level 5. We are learning all of the time. We will publish those data and make them available to give people some understanding as to why we are arriving at particular decisions in respect of how we exit level 5. I have already identified some areas that have been of concern that emanated from those particular data. For example
column18: in this phase we kept the schools and construction open. In the future
column19: the Deputy can take it that we would do things differently from how we did them even during level 5 and from the first phase. We are learning all the time. On mental health
column20: there are two sources of figures on self-harm
column21: the hospitals and clinical programmes. Hospitals could not report for a period of time due to Covid but reporting on statistics continued throughout Covid through the clinical programmes. I will qualify what I say here because we need more data and comprehensive research on this
column22: but at the moment the data from the clinical programmes show that there is no evidence of an increase in self-harm as the figures are broadly similar to those for the same period last year. I put a caveat on that until I am satisfied that there is a full
column23: comprehensive analysis of all the data. With regard to suicides
column24: there is a time lag as it has to be determined by the coroner. However
column25: a real-time local study of suicide incidence in Cork shows no significant increase on the 2019 figures. Interestingly
column26: a study on suicide in England found no evidence of a large national rise in post-lockdown suicide compared with previous lockdown suicides. It is an area that will continue to receive our attention.

column1: #MichaelMcNamara	unknown-#MichaelMcNamara-party	unknown-#MichaelMcNamara-dob	unknown-#MichaelMcNamara-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	45	I thank the Taoiseach. I greatly welcome his commitment to publishing data. I note that Ernst & Young have been brought in to crunch data. If those data are provided by the State or an organ of the State and collected with public moneys
column2: they should also be made available. The most important point is the evidence and data available to NPHET
column3: and the modelling code. Information about the code has been published but I am told by statisticians
column4: and I am not a statistician
column5: that it is not enough to do a comparison. To return to the mental health data
column6: I note the Taoiseach says there are data available. Will the Government publish the data that were available to it in the middle of October? The Taoiseach says the data are not complete but what was and was not available? We need to know that in a democracy. Will the Taoiseach commit to publishing that information? I am not asking him to get a lot of information. What information was available to the Government at the time and will he publish it by the end of this week or at least by this day next week? Also
column7: has any study been done on the impact of the mental health tribunals? We have changed how they operate. Has there been any study into the impact of the change in the way they operate on those who are affected
column8: that is
column9: those who are involuntarily detained?

column1: #MichaelMartin	unknown-#MichaelMartin-party	unknown-#MichaelMartin-dob	unknown-#MichaelMartin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	46	Recently
column2: at a Cabinet sub-committee meeting
column3: the Minister of State with responsibility for mental health
column4: Deputy Mary Butler
column5: presented a comprehensive report on mental health services generally but also in respect of the impact of Covid. Generally speaking
column6: services have been maintained at 90% or 95% throughout the Covid period
column7: which is a great credit to all of the professionals and staff involved. Very significant additional funding has been secured by the Minister of State for the mental health budget. Following that meeting
column8: we briefed the Deputy at a leaders' briefing meeting in respect of the information we had.

column1: #MichaelMcNamara	unknown-#MichaelMcNamara-party	unknown-#MichaelMcNamara-dob	unknown-#MichaelMcNamara-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	47	I am still waiting for that information.

#MichaelMartin	unknown-#MichaelMartin-party	unknown-#MichaelMartin-dob	unknown-#MichaelMartin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	48	I am giving it to the Deputy now. The information had come from the National Office for Suicide Prevention
column2: which is located in Cork. We will publish any data we have and send it to the Deputy. I have no difficulty with that. All data should be published. Data are there to inform public policy and public commentary
column3: so I have no issue with that. That was the presentation made by the Minister of State
column4: Deputy Butler
column5: at that Cabinet sub-committee meeting.

column1: #SeanOFearghaillFF	unknown-#SeanOFearghaillFF-party	unknown-#SeanOFearghaillFF-dob	unknown-#SeanOFearghaillFF-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	49	Thirty-one Deputies have already indicated

column1: #MaryLouMcDonald	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-party	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-dob	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	50	The continuing refusal by the Government and the Minister for Justice to come before this House to make a statement and take questions on the appointment to the Supreme Court is outrageous and unacceptable and I urge him to remedy that situation without any further delay. We have learned today that on the day his Government appointed Séamus Woulfe to the Supreme Court
column2: a second appointment was made to the Circuit Court. Can the Taoiseach explain to us his role in that appointment? The Tánaiste
column3: Deputy Leo Varadkar
column4: has confirmed that he knew that the person appointed to the Circuit Court had previously worked with the former Fine Gael Minister for Justice and Equality
column5: Deputy Charlie Flanagan. Was the Taoiseach aware of this when that appointment was made? Can he tell us how many applications or expressions of interest were made for that position on the Circuit Court? Can he confirm
column6: once and for all
column7: that there will be accountability here and that the Minister for Justice will present herself
column8: make a statement and take questions?

column1: #MichaelMartin	unknown-#MichaelMartin-party	unknown-#MichaelMartin-dob	unknown-#MichaelMartin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	51	In terms of accountability to the House
column2: and if I could be given a minute or two on this and pre-empt further questions
column3: I have answered questions on this issue twice on Leaders' Questions
column4: on 18 and 24 November
column5: with Deputy Shortall and
column6: if I am correct
column7: Deputy McDonald before that. The Tánaiste has taken Leaders' Questions three times on the appointment of Séamus Woulfe from Deputies Doherty
column8: Kelly and Catherine Murphy.There have been seven written questions from Deputy Kelly which I have answered.

#MichaelMartin	unknown-#MichaelMartin-party	unknown-#MichaelMartin-dob	unknown-#MichaelMartin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	66	There have been two from Deputy Shortall. The Minister
column2: Deputy McEntee
column3: has made it clear that she is willing to answer questions in this House. She said that last Thursday evening. The Opposition opposed that and any facilitation of that
column4: which was due to happen next Tuesday
column5: because of the format of how the questions would be asked. I believe withdrawing from the Business Committee based on the format of how questions are asked is wholly disproportionate. That is a reform that I championed. I believe in the Business Committee and I support its continuation. I want to make that clear. I spoke to the Ceann Comhairle this morning. The Ceann Comhairle has legal advice about the parameters and the nature of what can be asked. He is clear that questions must be on process and not commentary on the suitability of candidates or criteria
column6: which some Deputies asked me about earlier. The Minister
column7: Deputy McEntee
column8: and I discussed this issue. The Minister was taken aback last week when she made an offer to come into the House and answer questions-----

column1: #AlanKelly	unknown-#AlanKelly-party	unknown-#AlanKelly-dob	unknown-#AlanKelly-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	97	We have a period in Taoiseach's questions to return to this topic
column2: a Cheann Comhairle. That may facilitate you given the time that has been used. I object and find the way you are behaving in the Chamber today wrong.

column1: #SeanOFearghaillFF	unknown-#SeanOFearghaillFF-party	unknown-#SeanOFearghaillFF-dob	unknown-#SeanOFearghaillFF-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	98	Excuse me. The way who is behaving?

#AlanKelly	unknown-#AlanKelly-party	unknown-#AlanKelly-dob	unknown-#AlanKelly-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	99	The way the Taoiseach is behaving
column2: by not answering questions. That is utterly without precedent. I asked 18 questions of the Minister for Justice and the Taoiseach last week. The Taoiseach has repeatedly said that if Deputies have questions
column3: they should submit them and they will be answered. They are not being answered. One simple question that I asked was when the Taoiseach was informed that Mr. Justice Woulfe was to be appointed. No date was provided. All 18 questions were merged into one generic
column4: rubbish answer from the Minister for Justice and the Taoiseach. I will seek to meet the Ceann Comhairle later today to discuss how we will go forward. I have been down this road before with Ministers and I will not stop until I get my questions answered. The people of Tipperary put me here to hold this Taoiseach and Minister for Justice to account
column5: and it is my intention to do so. We will get there
column6: slice by slice. The Taoiseach can trust me on that. Before I ask my question on promised legislation
column7: I want to express my condolences to Damien Carrick
column8: Ciarán
column9: Ríoghna
column10: Sorcha and Eoin on the death of Trish. I have had some dealings with Damien. Ar dheis Dé go raibh a h-anam. I asked the Taoiseach to consult party leaders before making decisions on the changes that will be brought about post level 5
column11: which he is to announce on Friday. He has not done so
column12: which is his prerogative. It is wrong. It is too late now and it is wrong. I offer my commiserations on last Sunday
column13: when my county beat the Taoiseach's county. It is slightly ridiculous that for the sake of ten or 15 extra people
column14: full panels cannot be allowed at all-Ireland semi-finals and finals. I presume common sense will prevail on this.

column1: #SeanOFearghaillFF	unknown-#SeanOFearghaillFF-party	unknown-#SeanOFearghaillFF-dob	unknown-#SeanOFearghaillFF-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	100	The Deputy's time is up.

#AlanKelly	unknown-#AlanKelly-party	unknown-#AlanKelly-dob	unknown-#AlanKelly-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	101	If the Government is going to allow inter-county travel from a certain date in December
column2: there are workers
column3: particularly in healthcare
column4: who give up their time at Christmas to allow people with young children to be at home at Christmas.

column1: #SeanOFearghaillFF	unknown-#SeanOFearghaillFF-party	unknown-#SeanOFearghaillFF-dob	unknown-#SeanOFearghaillFF-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	102	The Deputy's time is up.

#AlanKelly	unknown-#AlanKelly-party	unknown-#AlanKelly-dob	unknown-#AlanKelly-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	103	I am finishing. These healthcare workers give up their time. Will the ban on travel between counties be lifted to allow healthcare workers to travel over the new year period? People should be able to travel until early January so they can go home and see their loved ones. For some workers
column2: New Year's Eve is more important than Christmas Day because they have to relieve people with young families over the Christmas period.

column1: #MichaelMartin	unknown-#MichaelMartin-party	unknown-#MichaelMartin-dob	unknown-#MichaelMartin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	104	I take strong exception to the Deputy's remarks. I have repeatedly answered questions in here and I have answered the Deputy too.

#MichaelMartin	unknown-#MichaelMartin-party	unknown-#MichaelMartin-dob	unknown-#MichaelMartin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	107	I am committed to the separation of powers. I am not so sure the Deputy is.

#AlanKelly	unknown-#AlanKelly-party	unknown-#AlanKelly-dob	unknown-#AlanKelly-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	108	It has nothing to do with the separation of powers. The separation of powers is the reason for asking the question.

#MichaelMartin	unknown-#MichaelMartin-party	unknown-#MichaelMartin-dob	unknown-#MichaelMartin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	109	The Deputy needs to come clean. At the beginning of this
column2: he suggested to me that I should seek the publication of correspondence.

#MichaelMartin	unknown-#MichaelMartin-party	unknown-#MichaelMartin-dob	unknown-#MichaelMartin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	117	That is an important issue. The Deputy has come in week after week to create a melodrama that is disproportionate to the issue.

#SeanOFearghaillFF	unknown-#SeanOFearghaillFF-party	unknown-#SeanOFearghaillFF-dob	unknown-#SeanOFearghaillFF-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	118	We look to the leaders to supply leadership and set examples. Maybe we can stop the clock for a minute. People have understandably been asking the Taoiseach if the Minister will come in and answer questions. He has told us that he wants the Business Committee to meet. I will convene a meeting of the Business Committee this afternoon with a view to seeing what arrangements can be made for the Minister for Justice
column2: Deputy McEntee
column3: to come in. Are we saying that he does not want the Minister to come in tomorrow?

column1: #MattieMcGrath	unknown-#MattieMcGrath-party	unknown-#MattieMcGrath-dob	unknown-#MattieMcGrath-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	119	We are not.

#MaryLouMcDonald	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-party	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-dob	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	121	We want a statement.

#PadraigMacLochlainn	unknown-#PadraigMacLochlainn-party	unknown-#PadraigMacLochlainn-dob	unknown-#PadraigMacLochlainn-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	122	We want a statement.

Members have repeatedly requested that the Minister for Justice come to the House. I ask Deputy McDonald to resume her seat. The Taoiseach has come in and said that he would request the Business Committee to meet. I am prepared to convene the Business Committee this afternoon
column2: with a view to arranging a meeting here at which the Minister for Justice would answer the questions that Members have.Are we now saying that we do not want to do that? Is that what Deputies are saying? If that is the case
column3: let us move on
column4: please.

column2: we are not.
