column1: Amendment of section 71 of Finance Act 2005
76. Section 71 of the Finance Act 2005 is amended—(a) in subsection (1)
column2: by the deletion of the definitions of “Community” and “Member State”
column3: (b) in subsection (5)
column4: by the substitution of “Subject to subsection (5A)
column5: a word” for“A word”
column6: and(c) by the insertion of the following subsection after subsection (5):“(5A) In this Chapter
column7: each reference to Member State shall apply as if the reference included a reference to Northern Ireland.”.”.The background to the amendment is that EU excise laws provide the legal framework for the application of excise duty to alcohol
column8: tobacco and mineral oil products and the minimum rates that apply. As a result of the Ireland and Northern Ireland protocol
column9: EU excise laws will apply to and in Northern Ireland from the end of the UK transition period. The changes proposed in the amendment are designed to ensure that our primary legislation on excise is consistent with the protocol by including Northern Ireland in the definitions of "Member State" and "European Union". We have had this in respect of a number of other sections. While Northern Ireland will not be a member of the EU
column10: it is being designated as a member state or in the EU under the Ireland and Northern Ireland protocol. We have had similar amendments on the same issue under other tax headings.

column1: #SeanOFearghaillFF	unknown-#SeanOFearghaillFF-party	unknown-#SeanOFearghaillFF-dob	unknown-#SeanOFearghaillFF-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	371	Amendments Nos. 14 and 15 are out of order.

#SeanOFearghaillFF	unknown-#SeanOFearghaillFF-party	unknown-#SeanOFearghaillFF-dob	unknown-#SeanOFearghaillFF-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	372	Amendment No. 16 is out of order.

#SeanHaughey	unknown-#SeanHaughey-party	unknown-#SeanHaughey-dob	unknown-#SeanHaughey-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	373	I wish to refer to the European arrest warrant. I raised this issue on Second Stage. Will the Minister for Justice confirm that the European Commission has issued Ireland a legal warning over delays in extraditing criminal suspects? It is my understanding that suspects wanted in other EU states should be extradited within two to three months. In 2019
column2: 59 suspects were not extradited within the required timeframe. The explanation for this could be that the Garda needs more resources for extradition cases or the High Court is delaying in dealing with the applications. I will agree to this section. It is necessary if we are to put in place new arrangements to deal with extraditions to the UK in the context of Brexit. Will the Minister confirm whether Ireland has been warned by the European Commission? Is she concerned about it? What will the Department of Justice do about it?

column1: #HelenMcEntee	unknown-#HelenMcEntee-party	unknown-#HelenMcEntee-dob	unknown-#HelenMcEntee-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	374	There is an issue with resources but delays are matters for the courts to adjudicate on. We are studying the correspondence from the Commission and are taking the matter seriously. As the Deputy outlined
column2: this part of the Bill is important. It deals with extradition and provides for amendments to the Extradition Act 1965. One of the key issues that has been identified by my Department is the need to ensure that we have efficient arrangements between Ireland and the UK in place and that they can be maintained. In a no-deal scenario
column3: the European arrest warrant would no longer apply to the UK. As such
column4: this section of the Bill is important. We only received the Commission's correspondence recently. We are taking it seriously. There is an issue with resources but applications are for the courts to adjudicate on.

column1: #SeanHaughey	unknown-#SeanHaughey-party	unknown-#SeanHaughey-dob	unknown-#SeanHaughey-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	375	I thank the Minister for replying on this matter. We are good Europeans. If the Commission has issued a legal warning to Ireland
column2: it is a serious issue and needs to be addressed. We are all familiar with the separation of powers and the High Court is doing its business. However
column3: if it is a case of the Garda not dealing with offences that it does not consider serious
column4: the House
column5: in particular the Minister
column6: would have to address the matter. I appreciate what the Minister has said. I hope that
column7: as good Europeans
column8: we will address the issue in due course.

column1: #BrendanHowlin	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-party	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-dob	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	376	I wish to ask about the procedure for extraditing someone from a third country
column2: which will include the UK next year. Such an extradition normally goes through diplomatic channels on application to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Will the Minister for Justice briefly indicate to us the new procedure that this section will provide? Will the Minister for Foreign Affairs devolve authority in order that the application can be made directly to the Minister for Justice by electronic means rather than the usual diplomatic means and the exchange of paper? Will the Minister
column3: Deputy McEntee
column4: give us a brief synopsis of the new process as she envisages extradition post January?

column1: #HelenMcEntee	unknown-#HelenMcEntee-party	unknown-#HelenMcEntee-dob	unknown-#HelenMcEntee-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	377	The process will not go through diplomatic channels. It will go to the Minister for Justice by electronic means.

#BrendanHowlin	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-party	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-dob	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	378	I wish to ask a general question about the operation of the Dublin Convention in respect of the UK post January. Is there a bilateral agreement with the UK on accepting asylum applicants back? Will the Dublin Convention's provisions continue to apply?

#HelenMcEntee	unknown-#HelenMcEntee-party	unknown-#HelenMcEntee-dob	unknown-#HelenMcEntee-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	379	The extradition and international protection arrangements will operate in a reciprocal fashion
column2: as will the common travel arrangements
column3: to which the next section relates. The arrangements will not necessarily be done using the same mechanisms as we are proposing in this section
column4: but there will be some form of reciprocal arrangement in place.

column1: #BrendanHowlin	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-party	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-dob	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	380	Do we know what will happen from 1 January? I am aware of asylum applicants in my constituency who have transited the UK and would in normal circumstances be subject to being returned to there under the Dublin Convention's provisions. Will that situation continue to operate from January onwards?

#HelenMcEntee	unknown-#HelenMcEntee-party	unknown-#HelenMcEntee-dob	unknown-#HelenMcEntee-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	381	I am informed that the regulations will not be exactly the same as the Dublin Convention's
column2: but they will be similar. I am unsure of whether they have been implemented yet.

column1: #ThomasByrne	unknown-#ThomasByrne-party	unknown-#ThomasByrne-dob	unknown-#ThomasByrne-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	386	Ba mhaith liom mo bhuíochas a ghabháil le gach duine a ghlac páirt sa díospóireacht seo inniu. Tá sé an-tábhachtach go bhfuilimid go léir aontaithe maidir leis an mBreatimeacht agus gabhaimid buíochas leis an bhFreasúra as an gcomhoibriú atá déanta acu anseo. I would like to express my thanks to all parties
column2: including the Opposition parties
column3: and Ministers who have co-operated on and contributed to what is an important Bill that is very much in the national interest. I accept all of the contributions that have been made. We divided on an issue which is of national import rather than on the overall international Brexit situation
column4: but I appreciate the sentiments expressed by Deputies. I would emphasise that we appreciate the united approach to being taken in the House on Brexit.  The Bill is necessary
column5: deal or no deal
column6: and the most important message that should come out of this debate to our citizens
column7: businesses and the British people is that whatever happens in terms of a deal in the negotiations – we wish our negotiators well – there will be significant changes when the transition period ends. I strongly encourage people who are affected by Brexit
column8: in particular businesses
column9: to access resources at gov.ie
column10: and the financial supports available.  I want to thank Members for their co-operation. We will go to the Seanad and consider any amendments that are put forward there. It is very important that the Bill has been passed as quickly as possible. We will consider timetables before Christmas in terms of what happens in the Seanad. I thank Deputies for the debate and the continued united approach in the House on the Brexit issue.

column1: #BrendanHowlin	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-party	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-dob	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	387	There has been an extraordinary sense of common purpose in the approach to Brexit for the past four years. I have been privileged to work on the stakeholders' forum. We were briefed extraordinarily well every step of the way by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and everybody provided their input in common endeavour. That was the approach we took to the two omnibus Bills
column2: which are extraordinary creatures in legislative terms. A hybrid of different enactments has been piloted by the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Different sections were taken by different Ministers. We have to continue in common effort. There are many more hurdles to come.  In that vein
column3: if the Opposition is asked
column4: required and expected to be supportive
column5: a little bit of reciprocal respect is expected. What happened today when a Minister accepted an Opposition amendment during a two hour debate
column6: resiled from it at the last minute and called a vote on and defeated it leaves a sour taste in that common purpose. We will put that behind us because there will be an opportunity to address that issue again. It is an important issue for a sector of our economy. It is to be hoped our colleagues in the Seanad will be able to do something about that.  I wish the Minister for Foreign Affairs well in his endeavours. It is to be hoped that the very delicate phase that the trade negotiations are currently at will be overcome and we will have the best possible outcome - it will not be a good outcome – for all of our people as we approach a different relationship with the United Kingdom.

column1: #JohnBrady	unknown-#JohnBrady-party	unknown-#JohnBrady-dob	unknown-#JohnBrady-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	388	The debate has been broadly good. It has been united
column2: and that has certainly been my party's approach from the get-go. I concur with the comments from Deputy Howlin on some of the unfortunate scenes and developments during this debate. Let us not allow that to cloud the overall objective which was achieved. There is an opportunity to come back to what we have discussed. Our approach to Brexit has been good from the get-go
column3: as I said. There has been a united approach in trying to achieve the Irish protocol which thankfully became a common theme and demand across Europe.Europe has been steadfast in its defence of the Good Friday Agreement and its protections for Ireland. This legislation is very important. It is unlike the previous omnibus Bill
column4: which was put in place in case we hit a cliff edge. We now face that
column5: inevitably
column6: at the end of the year. We have probably done as much as we can from a legislation perspective
column7: but there is much more to be done. There have been some concerns and it is only appropriate that I voice them now. They are concerns from some of the leading human rights and equality organisations on the island
column8: which are deeply concerned about the impact that Brexit is having on the protection of rights and equality provisions in the Good Friday Agreement
column9: given that European law is critical for such supports. They have lobbied
column10: as have others
column11: to secure human rights protections in the EU-UK withdrawal agreement via the protocol
column12: which guaranteed there would be no diminution of human rights as a result of Brexit. Those groups believe
column13: however
column14: that there is still a threat to those rights and protections as a result of the UK Internal Market Bill and the risks associated with securing an EU-UK future relationship Bill. The groups
column15: unfortunately
column16: are not convinced that the Government is advocating strongly enough to ensure that those human rights protections will be secured in any agreement or in the event of no agreement. I am not speaking on my own behalf but echoing their concerns. They are not convinced that the Government is lobbying to ensure those protections will be on the table
column17: nor that despite their requests directly to the Government and the media coverage
column18: the Government will raise the issue at a European level or push it with the British. I do not want to finish on a down note but concerns remain. While we are about to pass this legislation and to bring it forward
column19: serious concerns have been expressed by some of the leading organisations and agencies that the Government is dropping the ball on these critical areas. I appeal to the Government to address these serious concerns. If it is the case that the Government is not doing enough about these issues - by the sounds of it
column20: it is not - it needs to up its game
column21: because they are critical.

column1: #SeanOFearghaillFF	unknown-#SeanOFearghaillFF-party	unknown-#SeanOFearghaillFF-dob	unknown-#SeanOFearghaillFF-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	389	Is someone else offering? I cannot see.

#ThomasByrne	unknown-#ThomasByrne-party	unknown-#ThomasByrne-dob	unknown-#ThomasByrne-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	390	Deputy Michael Healy-Rae.

#SeanOFearghaillFF	unknown-#SeanOFearghaillFF-party	unknown-#SeanOFearghaillFF-dob	unknown-#SeanOFearghaillFF-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	391	Sorry
column2: Deputy Healy-Rae. I do not normally miss you.

column1: #MichaelHealyRae	unknown-#MichaelHealyRae-party	unknown-#MichaelHealyRae-dob	unknown-#MichaelHealyRae-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	392	This place is too big; I have been indicating for quite a while. Obviously
column2: Brexit will cause an awful lot of upheaval and complications in many sectors of all our lives. I do not know whether it was good or bad fortune
column3: although I enjoyed it thoroughly
column4: to work with the excellent
column5: hard-working Oireachtas Joint Committee on European Union Affairs
column6: comprising all parties and none
column7: over a number of years while preparedness for Brexit was taking place. One issue that I have begged the Government to address relates to the urgent need for a bilateral agreement with Britain on the cross-border directive
column8: whereby people seeking urgent medical healthcare will be able to travel North to receive the excellent care they get in private hospitals
column9: and that our health service can pay for it. As recently as last weekend
column10: I sent a busload of patients from County Kerry to Belfast
column11: where they received excellent care in a manner in which they could afford to pay for it. The big problem is that
column12: right now
column13: I have more people ready to go
column14: before the danger zone of 31 December
column15: but there is such pressure on the hospital at the moment that it does not think it will be able to cater for all the patients coming from the South. Between 5
column16: 000 and 6
column17: 000 used that service last year. It is for care. There is nothing more important in this world
column18: in my book anyway
column19: than our two eyes
column20: because we have only two. If we lose one
column21: we will be down to one eye
column22: and if we lose that
column23: we will be down to nothing. Sadly
column24: I know people who have gone blind waiting to have cataracts removed in our country and that is wrong. I am again pleading with the Government to please come to some sort of arrangement or bilateral agreement with the UK Government whereby we will still be able to avail of cross-border initiatives such that the funding can be supplied and that these patients can receive treatment
column25: whether for their hips
column26: knees or cataracts. Many of these people are elderly but many are not. I thank the Ceann Comhairle for allowing me the opportunity to discuss the issue.

column1: #SeanOFearghaillFF	unknown-#SeanOFearghaillFF-party	unknown-#SeanOFearghaillFF-dob	unknown-#SeanOFearghaillFF-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	393	That is a very important matter that we know the Deputy is deeply concerned about. It was discussed twice earlier and I suppose the third time helps emphasise the case.

#CianOCallaghan	unknown-#CianOCallaghan-party	unknown-#CianOCallaghan-dob	unknown-#CianOCallaghan-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	394	I echo the comments of other Deputies about the importance of the cross-party and unified approach to the issue. If we do end up with no trade deal
column2: and I very much hope we will not
column3: how that will impact tariffs
column4: the cost of living and food prices
column5: especially for low-income households
column6: will need immediate attention. I hope that is worked on on a cross-party and unified basis
column7: as everything else with respect to Brexit has been.

column1: #ThomasByrne	unknown-#ThomasByrne-party	unknown-#ThomasByrne-dob	unknown-#ThomasByrne-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	395	I again thank all Deputies for their genuine co-operation. I accept what they said and I think they accept the trust we need in the country's negotiation position. The negotiations in the days ahead will be difficult. I reiterate my message that no matter happens
column2: deal or no deal
column3: significant changes are coming and we need this legislation in order to ensure we are ready for that. I do not accept what Deputy Brady said about us not fighting for the human rights of citizens in Northern Ireland. Unfortunately
column4: the citizens of Northern Ireland are victims of a decision to leave the European Union taken by people across the sea from them. We have worked with might and main with every party in the House - the previous Government and this one - to ensure that the needs of the people of Ireland
column5: North and South
column6: would be top of the agenda. I am pleased to report that every Minister I speak to tells me they have two priorities for the negotiations
column7: namely
column8: the Good Friday Agreement and the rights of the citizens of Ireland
column9: and the European Single Market. Both issues are crucial to us and those in the North. I do not
column10: therefore
column11: accept that criticism. We are working very hard on this and the negotiators
column12: led by Michel Barnier
column13: the Commissioner who set up the PEACE programme for funding Border counties in the North
column14: are intimately aware of the issues facing the North and the wider island. I am grateful for all their input and everybody else's in the House. We are continuing to work on the cross-border treatment directive. Unfortunately
column15: this just one of the consequences of Britain leaving the European Union but the Taoiseach and the Minister for Health are working to try to find a solution. It presents difficulties but we want to solve it
column16: and I assure Deputies of that. These are not straightforward issues and others will undoubtedly transpire in the new year. There will be inconveniences and difficulties caused solely by the decision of the United Kingdom to leave the European Union. We as a nation - our businesses and citizens - have made significant preparations but there will be contingencies that we simply will not be able to deal with.There will be disadvantages to Britain leaving the European Union that will be completely outside of our control. There are huge changes coming. I encourage everybody to look at the resources available online
column17: including on gov.ie
column18: and I urge businesses to avail of the supports we are providing. As I said
column19: there are big changes coming.

column1: #SeanOFearghaillFF	unknown-#SeanOFearghaillFF-party	unknown-#SeanOFearghaillFF-dob	unknown-#SeanOFearghaillFF-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	396	The Select Committee on Finance
column2: Public Expenditure and Reform

#CatherineConnolly	unknown-#CatherineConnolly-party	unknown-#CatherineConnolly-dob	unknown-#CatherineConnolly-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	403	I will take a speaker from each group and I ask for Members' co-operation in this. I will give each group a chance to speak on the proposal
column2: beginning with Deputy Mac Lochlainn for Sinn Féin.

column1: #PadraigMacLochlainn	unknown-#PadraigMacLochlainn-party	unknown-#PadraigMacLochlainn-dob	unknown-#PadraigMacLochlainn-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	404	The Opposition has made a collective stand on this matter in recent days. Yesterday
column2: all of the Opposition Whips
column3: on behalf of our parties and political groups
column4: made a stand and said that the Minister for Justice must come before the democratically elected Dáil to take questions and answers. We have said this repeatedly. We told the Government that this issue would not go away and that respect must be given to the House. Whenever there is a matter of serious public concern
column5: we expect the Minister of the day to come into the Dáil to make a statement and take questions and answers. We told the Government it had to happen and now it is happening. However
column6: even now
column7: the Government could not do it with good grace. The Minister of State came into the Business Committee meeting today and gave us a fait accompli which included five minutes of questions and answers
column8: in real terms
column9: for every group. He knows that
column10: at best
column11: each speaker might get to put one or two questions. We are proud of the Opposition for taking the stand it took in defence of democracy in this State.

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	405	Hear
column2: hear.

column1: #PadraigMacLochlainn	unknown-#PadraigMacLochlainn-party	unknown-#PadraigMacLochlainn-dob	unknown-#PadraigMacLochlainn-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	406	The Minister of State is fooling nobody with his bad grace. The public knows that the Government was forced to do the right thing. I am proud of the collective Opposition. I wish to be clear on this point and I urge the Government to take the warning. We will stand up for democracy and we will demand accountability. It is clear to us that Fine Gael has a huge problem with accountability. It had better get used to it because this is what the Opposition will look like from now on.
#	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	407	Hear
column2: hear.

column1: #DuncanSmith	unknown-#DuncanSmith-party	unknown-#DuncanSmith-dob	unknown-#DuncanSmith-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	408	The Government has made an attempt to pitch those of us on this side of the House as only offering opposition for opposition's sake. It claimed that we go to meetings of the Business Committee and just have a big row. At the meeting today
column2: we spent 45 or 50 minutes putting forward alternative options and trying to make further compromises. We offered something we were not 100% happy with in an effort to get the Government to move from this fait accompli
column3: as Deputy Mac Lochlainn described it. We got nothing in return
column4: not one iota. The Government has been trying to box us into a particular position. It had the media briefed before the Business Committee meeting even happened today. We have operated in good faith
column5: consistently asking the same thing in the same keen way for the past two weeks and more. This is not right
column6: it is not democracy and it is not something we will stand for.

column1: #CatherineMurphy	unknown-#CatherineMurphy-party	unknown-#CatherineMurphy-dob	unknown-#CatherineMurphy-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	409	In terms of accountability
column2: what we are getting is five minutes per group for questions and answers. If we went into this and there was good faith shown by the Government
column3: that would be one thing. Instead
column4: the question it raises for me is what it is that the Government is afraid of. What has the Government got to hide?

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	410	Hear
column2: hear.

column1: #CatherineMurphy	unknown-#CatherineMurphy-party	unknown-#CatherineMurphy-dob	unknown-#CatherineMurphy-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	411	That it is hiding something is the only conclusion one can come to from this very contained scenario that is being offered. What is wrong with a forward and backward exchange with sufficient time - ten minutes
column2: say - to be used for questions and answers or statements
column3: whichever one wishes to do? That is the way we have done things in the recent past. I do not understand why there is a difference on this occasion. It only opens the matter up to further questions and further doubt.

column1: #RichardBoydBarrett	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-party	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-dob	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	412	The Government has spent well over a week trying to shield the Minister for Justice from questioning over the process of selection of Mr. Justice Séamus Woulfe to the Supreme Court. As a result of the collective insistence of the Opposition that the Minister come into the House to face questions and be accountable to the Dáil
column2: the Government was forced to put forward a proposal. That proposal will see the Minister coming in tomorrow
column3: but the Government has attempted to arrange it in such a way that for three quarters of the debate
column4: she will be shielded from any questions at all. That raises very serious questions about what the Government has to hide. At the meeting of the Business Committee today
column5: although we insisted that all of the time available to the Opposition should be given to direct questions and answers
column6: we were willing to compromise on that. We proposed one compromise whereby we would have some time for statements and a slightly longer time for questions. The Government would not accept that proposal. There was then a proposal from the Ceann Comhairle
column7: which we took up
column8: to split the time in half between statements and questions. The Government would not accept that either because it wanted absolutely to minimise the time in which the Minister would be subject to direct questioning. The public needs to ask itself why the Government is doing this if it does not have something to hide.

column1: #MattieMcGrath	unknown-#MattieMcGrath-party	unknown-#MattieMcGrath-dob	unknown-#MattieMcGrath-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	413	I am very sad to see what is happening. Speaking on behalf of the Rural Independent Group
column2: this is very bad politics. The Ceann Comhairle
column3: the Leas-Cheann Comhairle and everybody else who takes the Chair
column4: including myself
column5: knows that the separation of powers is sacrosanct. We are being warned that we cannot stray into certain areas. I understand that. However
column6: by giving ten minutes for statements and only five for questions
column7: it is giving more latitude for people to stray into areas they should not stray into. I do not know what the Government is hiding but something certainly is being hidden. It has been forced into this climbdown. We all objected yesterday to what was proposed and said that we would not attend the meeting of the Business Committee. When the Taoiseach announced today that the Minister was going to come into the House
column8: we agreed to go to the meeting. However
column9: that meeting was just a case of take it or leave it. We had a five-five vote and there was one missing.We had an extra person from the Government today with a vote and I want to ask the Leas-Cheann Comhairle
column10: if she or the Secretary General can tell me how come another Deputy was there who had never been at a Business Committee meeting before in my time. He was there when he was Whip and Minister of State
column11: Deputy Joe McHugh. They had an extra vote. It was massing the troops to keep the Opposition down all the time. This parlance looks to me like - I wish the Minister well and no disrespect - the youngest child in a big family
column12: and the newest girl
column13: and everybody else gathers around her to mind her and keep her safe. That is what it is. It is totally avoiding the responsibility. I believe the former Minister
column14: Deputy Flanagan
column15: did the work here and the Minister was only just sent in then with the note. It was a case of "Off you go with that now". The business was done long before that Cabinet meeting on 5 July. It is an unsavoury
column16: distasteful situation. It is shameful.

column1: #CatherineConnolly	unknown-#CatherineConnolly-party	unknown-#CatherineConnolly-dob	unknown-#CatherineConnolly-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	414	Deputy Pringle
column2: of the Independent Group.

column1: #ThomasPringle	unknown-#ThomasPringle-party	unknown-#ThomasPringle-dob	unknown-#ThomasPringle-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	415	I was going to say
column2: "Unfortunately
column3: I could not make the meeting today"
column4: but maybe it was fortunate because it sounds like it was a load of bunkum anyway. It justifies me in my decision to not attend the Business Committee. I had another meeting already arranged and that is why I did not make it today. It is clear that the Government
column5: in its gyrations to make sure the Minister is not accountable to the Dáil
column6: is hiding something. What it is doing is pointing even more to the fact that it is hiding something by the way it is going around it. It is nonsensical and ridiculous. It makes a mockery of the Business Committee. I hope the media will report this properly and show what the Government is doing. If Fianna Fáil was on this side of the House
column7: it would be pushing and leading the charge on this and because it is on the Government side now
column8: it wants to shut it down. That is the reality of the situation.

column1: #JackChambers	unknown-#JackChambers-party	unknown-#JackChambers-dob	unknown-#JackChambers-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	416	The Government
column2: in its proposal
column3: has put forward the exact formula and format that was agreed by the Business Committee in 2017 when Ms Justice Máire Whelan's appointment was questioned. At that time
column4: there was agreement from the Business Committee
column5: from the minority Government and from many Deputies who are now trying to construct this fake anger towards the constructive compromise proposal the Government has put forward. This format was agreed and approved. Many of the parties here who are opposing this proposal agreed with this format in 2017. The Minister has agreed to come before the Dáil and has agreed to answer any of the questions Members are putting forward
column6: and to make any other suggestion is unfair. In relation to the Business Committee meeting to which Deputy Mattie McGrath and others made reference
column7: it was five votes on each side. There was quite a balanced view at the Business Committee on this. It is also important to note that each time the Government comes up with a compromise and tries to propose something
column8: the Opposition shouts and roars. It is Sinn Féin competing against the far left. We have had many examples where we have tried to provide compromise and it has been voted down. We have a situation right now where we are proposing questions and answers
column9: we are proposing statements with those questions and answers and we have an Opposition opposing the very thing it sought. In the spirit of what we are trying to do with the Business Committee
column10: it is regrettable. It goes to show that with the minority trying to shout and roar at the Business Committee every week
column11: as well as here in the Dáil
column12: there has to be more of a constructive approach from Opposition and it must stop trying to promote an inaccurate representation of what the Minister has agreed to do-----

column1: #RichardBoydBarrett	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-party	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-dob	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	417	That is seriously disingenuous.

#JackChambers	unknown-#JackChambers-party	unknown-#JackChambers-dob	unknown-#JackChambers-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	418	-----which is to take questions and answers. That is happening tomorrow. That is the proposal that has been put forward. They can ask any questions they like and the Minister will answer them.

#RichardBoydBarrett	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-party	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-dob	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	419	We will be asking questions in the first ten minutes.

#JackChambers	unknown-#JackChambers-party	unknown-#JackChambers-dob	unknown-#JackChambers-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	420	That is the factual position and to say otherwise is untrue. It is the exact same format that was agreed in 2017 and is the precedence of the House in relation to the answering of questions relating to the appointment of judges.

#DuncanSmith	unknown-#DuncanSmith-party	unknown-#DuncanSmith-dob	unknown-#DuncanSmith-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	421	I do not wish to delay proceedings. Now that there is no votable business on the Order Paper for tomorrow
column2: would it be in order for us to move back to Leinster House and the Dáil Chamber for tomorrow's business? It is something the Labour Party would support. I hope the Government would be agreeable to that.

column1: #CatherineConnolly	unknown-#CatherineConnolly-party	unknown-#CatherineConnolly-dob	unknown-#CatherineConnolly-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	422	My difficulty is the arrangements have been made and the House is agreed that the Dáil will sit in the convention centre tomorrow.

#PadraigMacLochlainn	unknown-#PadraigMacLochlainn-party	unknown-#PadraigMacLochlainn-dob	unknown-#PadraigMacLochlainn-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	423	I support that proposal that we go back to the Dáil Chamber. For example
column2: the Leas-Cheann Comhairle will recall we had the issue around the confidence vote in the Tánaiste and we were able to bilocate when it was the Government that was requesting it. It is a reasonable request and I support it.

column1: #CatherineConnolly	unknown-#CatherineConnolly-party	unknown-#CatherineConnolly-dob	unknown-#CatherineConnolly-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	424	I have allowed the point of order. I understand that arrangements have been made. The Seanad is sitting in the Dáil Chamber tomorrow
column2: as I understand it
column3: and we cannot undo arrangements at this late stage. I am sorry. What the Deputies are asking for seems reasonable but that is the situation.

column1: #CatherineConnolly	unknown-#CatherineConnolly-party	unknown-#CatherineConnolly-dob	unknown-#CatherineConnolly-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	425	I must now deal with a postponed division relating to amendment No. 1 in the name of the Minister for Public Expenditure and Reform to the Second Stage motion on the Regulation of Lobbying (Amendment) Bill 2020. Yesterday
column2: on the question that the amendment be made
column3: a division was claimed and that division must be taken now.

column1: #CatherineConnolly	unknown-#CatherineConnolly-party	unknown-#CatherineConnolly-dob	unknown-#CatherineConnolly-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2020-11-25 00:00:00	Greyhound Industry: Motion [Private Members]	426	I must now deal with a postponed division relating to amendment No. 1 in the name of Minister of Agriculture
column2: Food and the Marine to the motion re funding for the Irish greyhound industry. This morning
column3: on the question
column4: "That the amendment be made"
column5: a division was claimed and that division must be taken now.
